article.title: One-out-of-two Quantum Oblivious Transfer based on Nonorthogonal States

choices: The error rate of the proposed QOT protocol compared to existing protocols.
The security level of the proposed QOT protocol compared to existing protocols.
The total quantum resource consumption of different QOT protocols for varying message lengths.
The relationship between transmission times and message length for different QOT protocols.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which protocol requires the fewest transmission times to complete the one-out-of-two QOT for a given message?
choices: Yang\'s protocol
YSW protocol
YYLSZ protocol
The proposed protocol

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Equation 3 demonstrate in the context of the MLC no-go theorem?
choices: The ability of a dishonest receiver (Bob) to learn both messages sent by Alice.
The ability of a dishonest sender (Alice) to determine the receiver\'s chosen bases after their selection.
The impossibility of unconditionally secure bit-commitment.
The relationship between the security level and the number of decoy qubits used in the protocol.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the variable Î¾ represent in Equation 4?
choices: The probability of a dishonest sender successfully executing an intercept-and-resend attack.
The probability of a dishonest sender successfully executing an entangling attack.
The security level of the protocol against internal attacks from a dishonest sender.
The security level of the protocol against internal attacks from a dishonest receiver.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Equation 7 illustrate in the context of the proposed protocol?
choices: How a dishonest sender (Alice) can learn the receiver\'s (Bob) chosen bases.
How a dishonest receiver (Bob) can potentially learn both messages sent by Alice.
The relationship between the immunity process and nonorthogonal states in the protocol.
The calculation for determining the total quantum resource consumption of the proposed protocol.
